mn115:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn115:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn115:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn115:2.1.pli: “Yāni kānici, bhikkhave, bhayāni uppajjanti sabbāni tāni bālato uppajjanti, no paṇḍitato;
mn115:2.1.eng: “Whatever dangers there are, all come from the foolish, not from the astute.
mn115:2.1.comm: Paṇḍita is normally used for a learned scholar, rather than a contemplative “sage”. Pali has many more terms for “a wise person” than does English, and it is not easy to distinguish the senses. “Astute” is meant to convey the sense of one who is observant and of sound judgment.

mn115:2.2.pli: ye keci upaddavā uppajjanti sabbe te bālato uppajjanti, no paṇḍitato;
mn115:2.2.eng: Whatever perils there are, all come from the foolish, not from the astute.

mn115:2.3.pli: ye keci upasaggā uppajjanti sabbe te bālato uppajjanti, no paṇḍitato.
mn115:2.3.eng: Whatever hazards there are, all come from the foolish, not from the astute.

mn115:2.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, naḷāgārā vā tiṇāgārā vā aggi mutto kūṭāgārānipi dahati ullittāvalittāni nivātāni phusitaggaḷāni pihitavātapānāni;
mn115:2.4.eng: It’s like a fire that spreads from a hut made of reeds or grass, and burns down even a bungalow, plastered inside and out, draft-free, with doors fastened and windows shuttered.

mn115:2.5.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yāni kānici bhayāni uppajjanti sabbāni tāni bālato uppajjanti, no paṇḍitato;
mn115:2.5.eng: In the same way, whatever dangers there are, all come from the foolish, not from the astute.

mn115:2.6.pli: ye keci upaddavā uppajjanti sabbe te bālato uppajjanti, no paṇḍitato;
mn115:2.6.eng: Whatever perils there are, all come from the foolish, not from the astute.

mn115:2.7.pli: ye keci upasaggā uppajjanti sabbe te bālato uppajjanti, no paṇḍitato.
mn115:2.7.eng: Whatever hazards there are, all come from the foolish, not from the astute.

mn115:2.8.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, sappaṭibhayo bālo, appaṭibhayo paṇḍito;
mn115:2.8.eng: So, the fool is dangerous, but the astute person is safe.

mn115:2.9.eng: The fool is perilous, but the astute person is not.

mn115:2.10.eng: The fool is hazardous, but the astute person is not.

mn115:2.11.pli: Natthi, bhikkhave, paṇḍitato bhayaṃ, natthi paṇḍitato upaddavo, natthi paṇḍitato upasaggo.
mn115:2.11.eng: There’s no danger, peril, or hazard that comes from the astute.

mn115:2.12.eng: So you should train like this: ‘We shall be astute, we shall be inquirers.’”

mn115:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn115:3.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,

mn115:3.2.pli: “kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, paṇḍito bhikkhu ‘vīmaṃsako’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti?
mn115:3.2.eng: “Sir, how is a mendicant qualified to be called ‘astute, an inquirer’?”
mn115:3.2.comm: Notice the different approaches used by Ānanda and Sāriputta in the previous discourse. Sāriputta took up the Buddha’s teaching and elaborated it, whereas Ānanda uses inquiry to prompt the Buddha himself to speak further.

mn115:3.3.pli: “Yato kho, ānanda, bhikkhu dhātukusalo ca hoti, āyatanakusalo ca hoti, paṭiccasamuppādakusalo ca hoti, ṭhānāṭhānakusalo ca hoti—
mn115:3.3.eng: “Ānanda, it’s when a mendicant is skilled in the elements, in the sense fields, in dependent origination, and in the possible and the impossible.

mn115:3.4.pli: ettāvatā kho, ānanda, paṇḍito bhikkhu ‘vīmaṃsako’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti.
mn115:3.4.eng: That’s how a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘astute, an inquirer’.”

mn115:4.1.eng: “But sir, how is a mendicant qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’?”
mn115:4.1.comm: As emphasized in this sutta, the notion of an “element” (dhātu) is a flexible one, including a range of different properties, qualities, or aspects of existence.

mn115:4.2.comm: These eighteen elements are mentioned only twice elsewhere in the Suttas (SN 14.1:2.2, SN 41.2:3.10), and hundreds of times in the Abhidhamma, where they are classified specifically as an Abhidhamma teaching (Vb 3:32.1).

mn115:4.3.eng: The eye element, sight element, and eye consciousness element.

mn115:4.4.eng: The ear element, sound element, and ear consciousness element.

mn115:4.5.eng: The nose element, smell element, and nose consciousness element.

mn115:4.6.eng: The tongue element, taste element, and tongue consciousness element.

mn115:4.7.eng: The body element, touch element, and body consciousness element.

mn115:4.8.eng: The mind element, ideas element, and mind consciousness element.
mn115:4.8.comm: The “mind element” (manodhātu) is not defined in the Suttas. See MN 28:37.1 and note there. The Abhidhamma Vibhaṅga says that the mind element arises immediately after a sense impression or engagement with mental phenomena or “ideas” (Vb 3:48.2), and the mind consciousness element arises immediately after the corresponding mind element (Vb 3:55.2).

mn115:4.9.pli: Imā kho, ānanda, aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo yato jānāti passati—
mn115:4.9.eng: When a mendicant knows and sees these eighteen elements,

mn115:4.10.eng: they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’.”

mn115:5.1.pli: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo, yathā ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti?
mn115:5.1.eng: “But sir, could there be another way in which a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’?”
mn115:5.1.comm: The method of building a lengthy discourse by asking for “another way” of exposition is also used at MN 9, SN 44.6, AN 5.106, and Snp 3.12.

mn115:5.4.pli: pathavīdhātu, āpodhātu, tejodhātu, vāyodhātu, ākāsadhātu, viññāṇadhātu.
mn115:5.4.eng: the elements of earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.

mn115:5.5.pli: Imā kho, ānanda, cha dhātuyo yato jānāti passati—
mn115:5.5.eng: When a mendicant knows and sees these six elements,

mn115:5.6.eng: they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’.”

mn115:6.1.pli: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo, yathā ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti?
mn115:6.1.eng: “But sir, could there be another way in which a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’?”

mn115:6.4.pli: sukhadhātu, dukkhadhātu, somanassadhātu, domanassadhātu, upekkhādhātu, avijjādhātu.
mn115:6.4.eng: the elements of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, equanimity, and ignorance.

mn115:6.5.pli: Imā kho, ānanda, cha dhātuyo yato jānāti passati—
mn115:6.5.eng: When a mendicant knows and sees these six elements,

mn115:6.6.eng: they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’.”

mn115:7.1.pli: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo, yathā ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti?
mn115:7.1.eng: “But sir, could there be another way in which a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’?”

mn115:7.4.pli: kāmadhātu, nekkhammadhātu, byāpādadhātu, abyāpādadhātu, vihiṃsādhātu, avihiṃsādhātu.
mn115:7.4.eng: the elements of sensuality and renunciation, malice and good will, and cruelty and harmlessness.

mn115:7.5.pli: Imā kho, ānanda, cha dhātuyo yato jānāti passati—
mn115:7.5.eng: When a mendicant knows and sees these six elements,

mn115:7.6.eng: they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’.”

mn115:8.1.pli: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo, yathā ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti?
mn115:8.1.eng: “But sir, could there be another way in which a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’?”

mn115:8.4.eng: the elements of the sensual realm, the realm of luminous form, and the formless realm.

mn115:8.5.pli: Imā kho, ānanda, tisso dhātuyo yato jānāti passati—
mn115:8.5.eng: When a mendicant knows and sees these three elements,

mn115:8.6.eng: they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’.”

mn115:9.1.pli: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo, yathā ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti?
mn115:9.1.eng: “But sir, could there be another way in which a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’?”

mn115:9.4.eng: the conditioned element and the unconditioned element.

mn115:9.5.pli: Imā kho, ānanda, dve dhātuyo yato jānāti passati—
mn115:9.5.eng: When a mendicant knows and sees these two elements,

mn115:9.6.eng: they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’.”

mn115:10.1.eng: “But sir, how is a mendicant qualified to be called ‘skilled in the sense fields’?”
mn115:10.1.comm: Ānanda moves on to the next topic, the six senses. Perhaps this move was prompted by the mention of the “unconditioned element” of Nibbana, signifying that that method of analysis had reached its culmination.

mn115:10.2.eng: “There are these six interior and exterior sense fields:

mn115:10.3.pli: cakkhu ceva rūpā ca sotañca saddā ca ghānañca gandhā ca jivhā ca rasā ca kāyo ca phoṭṭhabbā ca mano ca dhammā ca.
mn115:10.3.eng: the eye and sights, the ear and sounds, the nose and smells, the tongue and tastes, the body and touches, and the mind and ideas.

mn115:10.4.pli: Imāni kho, ānanda, cha ajjhattikabāhirāni āyatanāni yato jānāti passati—
mn115:10.4.eng: When a mendicant knows and sees these six interior and exterior sense fields,

mn115:10.5.eng: they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the sense fields’.”

mn115:11.1.eng: “But sir, how is a mendicant qualified to be called ‘skilled in dependent origination’?”

mn115:11.3.pli: ‘imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti, imassuppādā idaṃ uppajjati,
mn115:11.3.eng: ‘When this exists, this comes to be; due to the arising of this, this arises.

mn115:11.4.pli: imasmiṃ asati idaṃ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhati, yadidaṃ—
mn115:11.4.eng: When this doesn’t exist, this doesn’t come to be; due to the cessation of this, this ceases. That is:

mn115:11.5.eng: ignorance is a requirement for choices.

mn115:11.6.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness.

mn115:11.7.eng: Consciousness is a requirement for name and form.

mn115:11.8.eng: Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields.

mn115:11.9.eng: The six sense fields are requirements for contact.

mn115:11.10.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

mn115:11.11.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

mn115:11.12.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

mn115:11.13.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

mn115:11.14.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

mn115:11.15.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

mn115:11.16.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

mn115:11.17.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.

mn115:11.19.eng: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.

mn115:11.20.eng: When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease.

mn115:11.21.eng: When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases.

mn115:11.25.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

mn115:11.26.eng: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.

mn115:11.27.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

mn115:11.28.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’

mn115:11.29.eng: That’s how a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in dependent origination’.”

mn115:12.1.eng: “But sir, how is a mendicant qualified to be called ‘skilled in the possible and impossible’?”
mn115:12.1.comm: Said to be one of the ten powers of a Realized One (MN 12:10.1, AN 10.22:3.3), and to be restricted to those with meditative immersion (samādhi, AN 6.64:13.1). Each item here, split into separate suttas, is found at AN 1.168–295. Briefer examples of this trope are found at MN 122:3.2, SN 12.30, AN 6.70, and SN 6.93. These all focus on cause and effect as it pertains to development of the path.

mn115:12.2.pli: “Idhānanda, bhikkhu ‘aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo kañci saṅkhāraṃ niccato upagaccheyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:12.2.eng: “It’s when a mendicant understands: ‘It’s impossible for an individual accomplished in view to take any condition as permanent. That is not possible.
mn115:12.2.comm: A stream-enterer (or above) might unthinkingly act as if something were permanent (etc.), but on reflection they would know right away that this is not the case.

mn115:12.3.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ puthujjano kañci saṅkhāraṃ niccato upagaccheyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:12.3.eng: But it’s possible for an ordinary person to take some condition as permanent. That is possible.’

mn115:12.4.pli: ‘aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo kañci saṅkhāraṃ sukhato upagaccheyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:12.4.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for an individual accomplished in view to take any condition as pleasant.

mn115:12.5.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ puthujjano kañci saṅkhāraṃ sukhato upagaccheyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:12.5.eng: But it’s possible for an ordinary person to take some condition as pleasant.’

mn115:12.6.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo kañci dhammaṃ attato upagaccheyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti,
mn115:12.6.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for an individual accomplished in view to take anything as self.

mn115:12.7.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ puthujjano kañci dhammaṃ attato upagaccheyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:12.7.eng: But it’s possible for an ordinary person to take something as self.’

mn115:13.1.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo mātaraṃ jīvitā voropeyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:13.1.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for an individual accomplished in view to murder their mother.
mn115:13.1.comm: Murder of mother, father, or an arahant, injuring a Buddha, and causing schism are said to be specially heinous deeds that result in rebirth in hell.

mn115:13.2.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ puthujjano mātaraṃ jīvitā voropeyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:13.2.eng: But it’s possible for an ordinary person to murder their mother.’

mn115:13.3.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo pitaraṃ jīvitā voropeyya …pe…
mn115:13.3.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for an individual accomplished in view to murder their father … or murder a perfected one.

mn115:13.4.pli: arahantaṃ jīvitā voropeyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:13.4.eng: But it’s possible for an ordinary person to murder their father … or a perfected one.’

mn115:13.5.pli: ‘aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo duṭṭhacitto tathāgatassa lohitaṃ uppādeyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:13.5.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for an individual accomplished in view to injure a Realized One with malicious intent.

mn115:13.6.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ puthujjano duṭṭhacitto tathāgatassa lohitaṃ uppādeyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:13.6.eng: But it’s possible for an ordinary person to injure a Realized One with malicious intent.’

mn115:13.7.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo saṅghaṃ bhindeyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:13.7.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for an individual accomplished in view to cause a schism in the Saṅgha.

mn115:13.8.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ puthujjano saṅghaṃ bhindeyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:13.8.eng: But it’s possible for an ordinary person to cause a schism in the Saṅgha.’

mn115:13.9.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo aññaṃ satthāraṃ uddiseyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:13.9.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for an individual accomplished in view to dedicate themselves to another teacher.
mn115:13.9.comm: This does not mean that they cannot learn from another teacher; rather, they know that the Buddha’s path leads to liberation because they have realized it for themselves.

mn115:13.10.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ puthujjano aññaṃ satthāraṃ uddiseyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:13.10.eng: But it’s possible for an ordinary person to dedicate themselves to another teacher.’

mn115:14.1.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ ekissā lokadhātuyā dve arahanto sammāsambuddhā apubbaṃ acarimaṃ uppajjeyyuṃ, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:14.1.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for two perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas to arise in the same solar system at the same time.
mn115:14.1.comm: A lokadhātu is a single system with an earth, a sun and moon, planets, and a set of heavenly realms. Thus with due allowance for the different context, it is similar to a “solar system”. While many Buddhas may arise in the same solar system, they may not arise in the same region at the same time. There may, however, be many Buddhas simultaneously throughout the galaxy, an idea developed in later texts (eg. Mahāvastu 1.122).

mn115:14.2.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ ekissā lokadhātuyā eko arahaṃ sammāsambuddho uppajjeyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:14.2.eng: But it is possible for just one perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, to arise in one solar system.’

mn115:14.3.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ ekissā lokadhātuyā dve rājāno cakkavattino apubbaṃ acarimaṃ uppajjeyyuṃ, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:14.3.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for two wheel-turning monarchs to arise in the same solar system at the same time.
mn115:14.3.comm: A wheel-turning monarch was conceived as establishing dominion over the entire land from ocean to ocean, which apparently was believed to be the civilized world at the time the myth was created.

mn115:14.4.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ ekissā lokadhātuyā eko rājā cakkavattī uppajjeyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:14.4.eng: But it is possible for just one wheel-turning monarch to arise in one solar system.’

mn115:15.1.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ itthī arahaṃ assa sammāsambuddho, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:15.1.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a woman to be a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
mn115:15.1.comm: It is unclear why this is mentioned, and since the Chinese parallel MA 181 lacks this passage entirely, it may be a later addition. It is of no apparent spiritual relevance, since in early Buddhist texts there is no concept of aspiring to become a Buddha in future lives. A woman may, of course, realize full liberation as an arahant, so the issue is not spiritual prowess. As to the reasoning underlying the claim, in this passage the Buddha is followed by a wheel-turning monarch, Sakka, Māra, and Brahmā. What they all have in common is that they are leaders. Since leaders of the time were men, perhaps it was assumed that people would not follow a woman in that role. This reasoning would also seem to be behind the idea that the Buddha was born either an aristocrat or a brahmin, whichever was the leading class of the time (DN 14:1.5.1).

mn115:15.2.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ puriso arahaṃ assa sammāsambuddho, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:15.2.eng: But it is possible for a man to be a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.’

mn115:15.3.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ itthī rājā assa cakkavattī, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:15.3.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a woman to be a wheel-turning monarch.

mn115:15.4.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ puriso rājā assa cakkavattī, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:15.4.eng: But it is possible for a man to be a wheel-turning monarch.’

mn115:15.5.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ itthī sakkattaṃ kareyya … mārattaṃ kareyya … brahmattaṃ kareyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:15.5.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a woman to perform the role of Sakka, Māra, or the Divinity.
mn115:15.5.comm: While we encounter these divinities as individuals, they are understood as being stations or offices in the leading role of their particular realms. Thus, for example, Moggallāna said that he used to be Māra in a past life (MN 50:8.1).

mn115:15.6.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ puriso sakkattaṃ kareyya … mārattaṃ kareyya … brahmattaṃ kareyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:15.6.eng: But it is possible for a man to perform the role of Sakka, Māra, or the Divinity.’

mn115:16.1.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ kāyaduccaritassa iṭṭho kanto manāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:16.1.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a likable, desirable, agreeable result to come from bad conduct of body, speech, and mind.

mn115:16.2.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ kāyaduccaritassa aniṭṭho akanto amanāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:16.2.eng: But it is possible for an unlikable, undesirable, disagreeable result to come from bad conduct of body, speech, and mind.’

mn115:16.4.pli: yaṃ manoduccaritassa iṭṭho kanto manāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;

mn115:16.5.pli: ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ vacīduccaritassa …pe…

mn115:16.6.pli: yaṃ manoduccaritassa aniṭṭho akanto amanāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatīti pajānāti.

mn115:17.1.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ kāyasucaritassa aniṭṭho akanto amanāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:17.1.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for an unlikable, undesirable, disagreeable result to come from good conduct of body, speech, and mind.

mn115:17.2.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ kāyasucaritassa iṭṭho kanto manāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:17.2.eng: But it is possible for a likable, desirable, agreeable result to come from good conduct of body, speech, and mind.’

mn115:17.4.pli: yaṃ manosucaritassa aniṭṭho akanto amanāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;

mn115:17.6.pli: yaṃ manosucaritassa iṭṭho kanto manāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.

mn115:18.1.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ kāyaduccaritasamaṅgī taṃnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:18.1.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible that someone who has engaged in bad conduct of body, speech, and mind, could for that reason alone, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
mn115:18.1.comm: The qualification “for that reason” (taṁnidānā tappaccayā) is essential, as it is quite possible for someone to engage in bad conduct and later take a good rebirth due to other deeds. This case is discussed in MN 136:18.1.

mn115:18.2.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ kāyaduccaritasamaṅgī taṃnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:18.2.eng: But it is possible that someone who has engaged in bad conduct of body, speech, and mind could, for that reason alone, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’

mn115:19.2.pli: yaṃ manoduccaritasamaṅgī taṃnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;

mn115:19.4.pli: yaṃ manoduccaritasamaṅgī taṃnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.

mn115:19.5.pli: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ kāyasucaritasamaṅgī taṃnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
mn115:19.5.eng: They understand: ‘It’s impossible that someone who has engaged in good conduct of body, speech, and mind could, for that reason alone, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

mn115:19.6.pli: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ kāyasucaritasamaṅgī taṃnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
mn115:19.6.eng: But it is possible that someone who has engaged in good conduct of body, speech, and mind could, for that reason alone, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’

mn115:19.8.pli: yaṃ manosucaritasamaṅgī taṃnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;

mn115:19.10.pli: yaṃ manosucaritasamaṅgī taṃnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.

mn115:19.11.eng: That’s how a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in the possible and impossible’.”

mn115:20.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn115:20.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,

mn115:20.3.eng: What is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”

mn115:20.4.pli: “Tasmātiha tvaṃ, ānanda, imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ ‘bahudhātuko’tipi naṃ dhārehi, ‘catuparivaṭṭo’tipi naṃ dhārehi, ‘dhammādāso’tipi naṃ dhārehi, ‘amatadundubhī’tipi naṃ dhārehi, ‘anuttaro saṅgāmavijayo’tipi naṃ dhārehī”ti.
mn115:20.4.eng: “Well then, Ānanda, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Many Elements’, or else ‘The Four Rounds’, or else ‘The Mirror of the Teaching’, or else ‘The Drum of Freedom From Death’, or else ‘The Supreme Victory in Battle’.”
mn115:20.4.comm: The “four rounds” are the four main topics (elements, sense fields, dependent origination, the possible and the impossible); elsewhere it is said to be the four noble truths (SN 22.56:2.1). | The “mirror of the teaching” is the ability of a noble one to see the truth of the Dhamma in themselves (SN 55.8:5.1, DN 16:2.8.3). | The “drum of freedom from death” was sounded by the Buddha after his awakening (MN 26:25.21). | The “supreme victory in battle” was also suggested as a title for the Brahmajālasutta (DN 1:3.74.3), while elsewhere it is said to be a name for the noble eightfold path (SN 45.4:4.3).

mn115:20.5.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn115:20.6.pli: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn115:20.6.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
